name: Element

aliases.name: Attribute
aliases.type: Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

aliases.name: Device
aliases.type: { width : Basics.Int, height : Basics.Int, phone : Basics.Bool, tablet : Basics.Bool, desktop : Basics.Bool, bigDesktop : Basics.Bool, portrait : Basics.Bool }

aliases.name: Element
aliases.comment:
You can think of an `Element` as `Html` with built-in layout.

It has one `style` identifier, which you can think of as a CSS class.

It can also have style `variations`, which are covered in the `Style` module.
aliases.type: Element.Internal.Model.Element style variation msg

aliases.name: Grid
aliases.type: { rows : List.List Element.Attributes.Length, columns : List.List Element.Attributes.Length, cells : List.List (Element.OnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)) }

aliases.name: GridPosition
aliases.type: { start : ( Basics.Int, Basics.Int ), width : Basics.Int, height : Basics.Int, content : Element.Element style variation msg }

aliases.name: NamedGrid
aliases.type: { rows : List.List ( Element.Attributes.Length, List.List Style.Internal.Model.NamedGridPosition ), columns : List.List Element.Attributes.Length, cells : List.List (Element.NamedOnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)) }

aliases.name: NamedGridPosition
aliases.type: Style.Internal.Model.NamedGridPosition

aliases.name: NamedOnGrid
aliases.type: Element.Internal.Model.NamedOnGrid thing

aliases.name: OnGrid
aliases.type: Element.Internal.Model.OnGrid thing

values.name: above
values.type: List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: article
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: aside
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: below
values.type: List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: button
values.comment:
Renders as a `<button>`

Also is able to receive keyboard focus.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: cell
values.comment: A specific position on a `grid`.
values.type: Element.GridPosition style variation msg -> Element.OnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)

values.name: circle
values.comment:
A simple circle. Provide the radius it should have.

Automatically sets the propery width, height, and corner rounded.
values.type: Basics.Float -> style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: classifyDevice
values.comment: Takes in a Window.Size and returns a device profile which can be used for responsiveness.
values.type: { window | width : Basics.Int, height : Basics.Int } -> Element.Device

values.name: column
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: decorativeImage
values.comment: If an image is purely decorative, you can skip the caption.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> { src : String.String } -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: download
values.comment:
Make a link that will download a file

    download "http://zombo.com/schedule.pdf"
        <| el MyStyle (text "Welcome to Zombocom")
values.type: String.String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: downloadAs
values.comment:
Make a link that will download a file and give it a specific filename.

    downloadAs
        { src = "http://zombo.com/schedule.pdf"
        , filename = "zombocomSchedule.pdf"
        }
        <| el MyStyle (text "Welcome to Zombocom")
values.type: { src : String.String, filename : String.String } -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: el
values.comment:
The most basic element.

You need to specify a style, a list of attributes, and a single child.

    -- an element with the style `MyStyle`, that is aligned left, and has one child.
    el MyStyle [ alignLeft ] (text "Hello World!")

`el` can only have one child because in order to have multiple children, we need to specify how the layout would work.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: embedStylesheet
values.comment: Embed a stylesheet.

values.name: footer
values.comment: This is the main page footer where your copyright and other infomation should live.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: full
values.comment:
A `full` element will ignore the spacing set for it by the parent, and also grow to cover the parent's padding.

This is mostly useful in text layouts.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: grid
values.comment:
An interface to css grid. Here's a basic example:

    grid MyGridStyle []
        { columns = [ px 100, px 100, px 100, px 100 ]
        , rows =
            [ px 100
            , px 100
            , px 100
            , px 100
            ]
        , cells =
             [ cell
                { start = ( 0, 0 )
                , width = 1
                , height = 1
                , content =
                    el Box [] (text "box")
                }
            , cell
                { start = ( 1, 1 )
                , width = 1
                , height = 2
                , content =
                    el Box [] (text "box")
                }
            ]
        }
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Grid style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: h1
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: h2
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: h3
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: h4
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: h5
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: h6
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: hairline
values.comment:
Creates a 1 px tall horizontal line.

If you want a horizontal rule that is something more specific, craft it with `el`!

values.name: header
values.comment: This is the main page header area.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: html
values.comment:
For when you want to embed `Html`.

If you're using this library, I'd encourage you to try to solve your problem without using this escape hatch.

Usage of this function makes the most sense when you're dealing with `Html` from another module or package or if you need to craft something "manually" yourself.
values.type: Html.Html msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: image
values.comment: For images, both a source and a caption are required. The caption will serve as the alt-text.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> { src : String.String, caption : String.String } -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: layout
values.comment: Embeds the stylesheet and renders the `Element`'s into `Html`.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: link
values.comment:
Turn an element into a link.

    link "http://zombo.com"
        <| el MyStyle [] (text "Welcome to Zombocom")

Wraps an element in an `<a>` and sets the href. `rel` properties are set to `noopener` and `noreferrer`.
values.type: String.String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: mainContent
values.comment: The main content of your page.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: map
values.comment:
Change the msg that an Element is sending.

An analog of `Html.map`.
values.type: (a -> msg) -> Element.Element style variation a -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: mapAll
values.comment: Map the msg, style, and variation that is used.
values.type: (msgA -> msgB) -> (styleA -> styleB) -> (variationA -> variationB) -> Element.Element styleA variationA msgA -> Element.Element styleB variationB msgB

values.name: modal
values.comment: This is a modal
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: named
values.comment: Specify a named postion on a `namedGrid`.
values.type: String.String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.NamedOnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)

values.name: namedGrid
values.comment:
With a named grid, you can name areas within the grid and use that name to place an element.

Here's an example:

    namedGrid MyGridStyle []
        { columns = [ px 200, px 200, px 200, fill 1 ]
        , rows =
            [ px 200 => [ spanAll "header" ]
            , px 200 => [ span 3 "content", span 1 "sidebar" ]
            , px 200 => [ span 3 "content", span 1 "sidebar" ]
            , px 200 => [ spanAll "footer" ]
            ]
        , cells =
            [ named "header"
                (el Box [] (text "box"))
            , named "sidebar"
                (el Box [] (text "box"))
            ]
        }

**note:** this example uses rocket(`=>`) as a synonym for creating a tuple. For more, check out the [rocket update](https://github.com/NoRedInk/rocket-update) package!
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.NamedGrid style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: navigation
values.comment:
The main navigation of the site, rendered as a row.

The required `name` is used by accessibility software to describe to non-sighted users what this navigation element pertains to.

Don't leave `name` blank, even if you just put _"Main Navigation"_ in it.

     navigation NavMenuStyle
        []
        { name = "Main Navigation"
        , options =
            [ link "/profile" (el NavLink [] (text "profile"))
            , link "/logout" (el NavLink [] (text "logout"))
            ]
        }
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> { options : List.List (Element.Element style variation msg), name : String.String } -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: navigationColumn
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> { options : List.List (Element.Element style variation msg), name : String.String } -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: newTab
values.comment:
Make a link that opens in a new tab.

Depending on the browsers configiration, it may open in a new window.

    newTab "http://zombo.com"
        <| el MyStyle (text "Welcome to Zombocom")

Same as `target "_blank"`
values.type: String.String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: node
values.type: String.String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: onLeft
values.type: List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: onRight
values.type: List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: paragraph
values.comment:
Paragraph is actually a layout if you can believe it!

This is the same as a textLayout, except all of the children are set to `display:inline`.

Because all the children are inline, they will not respect a width or height set on them.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: responsive
values.comment:
Define two ranges that should linearly match up with each other.

Provide a value for the first and receive the calculated value for the second.

    fontsize =
        responsive device.width ( 600, 1200 ) ( 16, 20 )

When the device width is between 600 and 1200, set the font-size between 16 and 20 using a linear scale.
values.type: Basics.Float -> ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> Basics.Float

values.name: row
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: screen
values.comment:
Position an element relative to the window.

Essentially the same as `display: fixed`.

If you're trying to make a modal, check out `Element.Location.modal`
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: search
values.comment:
An area that houses the controls for running a search.

While `Element.Input.search` will create a literal search input,
this element is meant to group all the controls that are involved with searching,
such as filters and the search button.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: section
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: sidebar
values.comment:
This is a sidebar which contains complementary information to your main content.

It's rendered as a column.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: spacer
values.comment:
An element for adding additional spacing. The `Float` is the multiple that should be used of the spacing that's being set by the parent.

So, if the parent element is a `column` that set spacing to `5`, and this spacer was a `2`. Then it would be a 10 pixel spacer.

values.name: span
values.comment: Used to define named areas in a `namedGrid`.

values.name: spanAll
values.comment: Used to define named areas in a `namedGrid`.

values.name: subheading
values.comment: Don't use a heading like `h2` if you want a subheading/subtitle, instead use this element!
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> String.String -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: table
values.comment: A table is a special grid
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (List.List (Element.Element style variation msg)) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: textLayout
values.comment:
A text layout.

Children that are aligned left or right will be floated left or right. Everything else is arranged in the standard 'block' layout of css, meaning a column flowing down.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: toHtml
values.comment: Renders `Element`'s into `Html`, but does not embed a stylesheet.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: viewport
values.comment: Same as `layout`, but the height and width of the site is set to the height and width of the screen.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: when
values.comment:
A helper function. This:

    when (x == 5) (text "yay, it's 5")

is sugar for

    if (x == 5) then
        text "yay, it's 5"
    else
        empty
values.type: Basics.Bool -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: whenJust
values.comment:
Another helper function that defaults to `empty`

    whenJust (Just ("Hi!")) text

is sugar for

    case maybe of
        Nothing ->
            empty
        Just x ->
            text x
values.type: Maybe.Maybe a -> (a -> Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: within
values.type: List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: wrappedColumn
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: wrappedRow
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

name: Element.Attributes
comment: # This module is a mirror of `Html.Attributes` Some attributes have been added. The only modification to the existing library is that `style` has been renamed `inlineStyle` to avoid collision with `Style.style`. Since this is a style library, you shouldn't need it very often. # Style Element Attributes These are the new attributes that generally have to do with layout. @docs hidden, vary ## Alignment Alignment attributes are incredibly useful for adjusting your layout. When applied to layout elements like `row` and `grid`, alignment will affect the alignment of the children. When applied to singular elements like `el`, alignment will affect the alignment of that individual element. @docs center, verticalCenter, alignTop, alignBottom, alignLeft, alignRight, spread, verticalSpread ## Sizing @docs width, minWidth, maxWidth, height, minHeight, maxHeight, Length, px, fill, fillPortion, percent, content ## Spacing ++ Padding Spacing allows a layout to set the distance between the children in the layout. So this layout: row [ spacing 10, padding 10 ] [ el Box [] empty , el Box [] empty , el Box [] empty ] Is rendered into something like this: @docs spacing, spacingXY, padding, paddingXY, paddingTop, paddingRight, paddingBottom, paddingLeft ## Positioning @docs moveUp, moveDown, moveRight, moveLeft ## Scrollbars @docs scrollbars, yScrollbar, xScrollbar ## Overflow @docs clip, clipX, clipY ## Conversion @docs toAttr # Primitives @docs inlineStyle, property, attribute, map # Super Common Attributes @docs class, classList, id

aliases.name: Length
aliases.type: Style.Internal.Model.Length

values.name: attribute
values.comment:
Create _attributes_, like saying `domNode.setAttribute('class', 'greeting')`
in JavaScript.

    class : String -> Attribute variation msg
    class =
        Html.Attributes.class

Read more about the difference between properties and attributes [here].

[here]: https://github.com/elm-lang/html/blob/master/properties-vs-attributes.md

values.name: class
values.comment: Often used with CSS to style elements with common properties.

values.name: classList
values.comment:
This function makes it easier to build a space-separated class attribute.
Each class can easily be added and removed depending on the boolean value it
is paired with. For example, maybe we want a way to view notices:

    viewNotice : Notice -> Html msg
    viewNotice notice =
        div
            [ classList
                [ ( "notice", True )
                , ( "notice-important", notice.isImportant )
                , ( "notice-seen", notice.isSeen )
                ]
            ]
            [ text notice.content ]
values.type: List.List ( String.String, Basics.Bool ) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: clip
values.comment: Clip content that overflows.

values.name: hidden
values.comment: Remove the element from the view.

values.name: id
values.comment:
Often used with CSS to style a specific element. The value of this
attribute must be unique.

values.name: inlineStyle
values.comment:
This is the manual override for to specify inline css properties.

    myStyle : Attribute msg
    myStyle =
        inlineStyle "backgroundColor" "red"

    greeting : Html msg
    greeting =
        el [ myStyle ] (text "Hello!")

Use it if you need to, though it's obviously recommended to use the `Style` module instead.

values.name: map
values.comment: Transform the messages produced by an `Attribute`.
values.type: (a -> msg) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation a -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: paddingXY
values.comment: Set horizontal and vertical padding.

values.name: property
values.comment:
Create _properties_, like saying `domNode.className = 'greeting'` in
JavaScript.

    import Json.Encode as Encode

    class : String -> Attribute variation msg
    class =
        Html.Attributes.class

Read more about the difference between properties and attributes [here].

[here]: https://github.com/elm-lang/html/blob/master/properties-vs-attributes.md

values.name: scrollbars
values.comment: Turn on scrollbars if content overflows.

values.name: spacing
values.comment: Set the spacing between children in a layout.

values.name: spacingXY
values.comment:
Set the horizontal and vertical spacing separately.

This is generally only useful in a textLayout or a grid.

values.name: toAttr
values.comment:
Convert an existing `Html.Attribute` to an `Element.Attribute`.

This is useful for working with any library that returns a `Html.Attribute`.

values.name: vary
values.comment:
Apply a style variation.

    el MyButton [ vary Disabled True ] (text "My Disabled Button!")

values.name: xScrollbar
values.comment: Turn on scrollbars if content overflows horizontally.

values.name: yScrollbar
values.comment: Turn on scrollbars if content overflows vertically.

name: Element.Events

values.name: custom
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder { message : msg, stopPropagation : Basics.Bool, preventDefault : Basics.Bool } -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: keyCode
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.keyCode`. This helps you define
keyboard listeners like this:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onKeyUp : (Int -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onKeyUp tagger =
        on "keyup" (Json.map tagger keyCode)

**Note:** It looks like the spec is moving away from `event.keyCode` and
towards `event.key`. Once this is supported in more browsers, we may add
helpers here for `onKeyUp`, `onKeyDown`, `onKeyPress`, etc.

values.name: on
values.comment:
Create a custom event listener. Normally this will not be necessary, but
you have the power! Here is how `onClick` is defined for example:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onClick : msg -> Attribute variation msg
    onClick message =
        on "click" (Json.succeed message)

The first argument is the event name in the same format as with JavaScript's
[`addEventListener`][aEL] function.
The second argument is a JSON decoder. Read more about these [here][decoder].
When an event occurs, the decoder tries to turn the event object into an Elm
value. If successful, the value is routed to your `update` function. In the
case of `onClick` we always just succeed with the given `message`.
If this is confusing, work through the [Elm Architecture Tutorial][tutorial].
It really does help!
[aEL]: <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener>
[decoder]: <http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/latest/Json-Decode>
[tutorial]: <https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/>
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder msg -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: onCheck
values.comment:
Capture [change](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/change)
events on checkboxes. It will grab the boolean value from `event.target.checked`
on any input event.
Check out [targetChecked](#targetChecked) for more details on how this works.

values.name: onInput
values.comment:
Capture [input](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/input)
events for things like text fields or text areas.
It grabs the **string** value at `event.target.value`, so it will not work if
you need some other type of information. For example, if you want to track
inputs on a range slider, make a custom handler with [`on`](#on).
For more details on how `onInput` works, check out [targetValue](#targetValue).

values.name: onSubmit
values.comment:
Capture a [submit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/submit)
event with [`preventDefault`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault)
in order to prevent the form from changing the pageâ€™s location. If you need
different behavior, use `onWithOptions` to create a customized version of
`onSubmit`.

values.name: preventDefaultOn
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder ( msg, Basics.Bool ) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: stopPropagationOn
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder ( msg, Basics.Bool ) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: targetChecked
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.target.checked`. We use this to define
`onCheck` as follows:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onCheck : (Bool -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onCheck tagger =
        on "input" (Json.map tagger targetChecked)

values.name: targetValue
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.target.value`. We use this to define
`onInput` as follows:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onInput : (String -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onInput tagger =
        on "input" (Json.map tagger targetValue)

You probably will never need this, but hopefully it gives some insights into
how to make custom event handlers.

name: Element.Input

unions.name: Choice
unions.comment: Add choices to your radio and select menus.

aliases.name: Checkbox
aliases.type: { onChange : Basics.Bool -> msg, label : Element.Element style variation msg, checked : Basics.Bool, options : List.List (Element.Input.Option style variation msg) }

aliases.name: Radio
aliases.type: { onChange : option -> msg, choices : List.List (Element.Input.Choice option style variation msg), selected : Maybe.Maybe option, label : Element.Input.Label style variation msg, options : List.List (Element.Input.Option style variation msg) }

aliases.name: Select
aliases.type: { with : Element.Input.SelectWith option msg, max : Basics.Int, menu : Element.Input.Menu option style variation msg, label : Element.Input.Label style variation msg, options : List.List (Element.Input.Option style variation msg) }

aliases.name: StyledCheckbox
aliases.type: { onChange : Basics.Bool -> msg, label : Element.Element style variation msg, checked : Basics.Bool, options : List.List (Element.Input.Option style variation msg), icon : Basics.Bool -> Element.Element style variation msg }

aliases.name: Text
aliases.type: { onChange : String.String -> msg, value : String.String, label : Element.Input.Label style variation msg, options : List.List (Element.Input.Option style variation msg) }

values.name: allowSpellcheck
values.comment: Allow spellcheck for this input. Only works on text based inputs.

values.name: autocomplete
values.comment:
Create a `select` menu which shows options that are filtered by the text entered.

This is the part which goes in your model.

You'll need to update it using `Input.updateSelection`.

Once you have this in your model, you can extract the current selected value from it using `Input.selected model.autocompleteState`.
values.type: Maybe.Maybe option -> (Element.Input.SelectMsg option -> msg) -> Element.Input.SelectWith option msg

values.name: autofill
values.comment:
Give a hint to the browser on what data can be used to autofill this input.

This can be very useful to allow the browser to autofill address and credit card forms.

For more general information check out the [`autocomplete` attribute of `input` elements](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/Input)

values.name: checkbox
values.comment:
Your basic checkbox

    Input.checkbox Checkbox
        []
        { onChange = Check
        , checked = model.checkbox
        , label = el None [] (text "hello!")
        , options = []
        }
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Checkbox style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: choice
values.type: value -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Input.Choice value style variation msg

values.name: clear
values.comment: Clear a selection.
values.type: Element.Input.SelectWith option msg -> Element.Input.SelectWith option msg

values.name: currentPassword
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: disabled
values.comment:
Disable an input. This means that the input will not receive focus and can't be changed by the user.

Does not change the styling of the inputs unless they're controlled by the browser like a basic checkbox or standard radio button.

values.name: dropMenu
values.comment:
Create a `select` menu which shows all options and allows the user to select one.

Use this if you only have 3-5 options. If you have a ton of options, use `Input.autocomplete` instead!

Once you have this in your model, you can extract the current selected value from it using `Input.selected model.dropMenuState`.
values.type: Maybe.Maybe option -> (Element.Input.SelectMsg option -> msg) -> Element.Input.SelectWith option msg

values.name: email
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: errorAbove
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Input.Option style variation msg

values.name: errorBelow
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Input.Option style variation msg

values.name: focusOnLoad
values.comment:
Put the focus on this input when the page loads.

Only one input should have this option turned on.

values.name: labelAbove
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Input.Label style variation msg

values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Input.Label style variation msg

values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Input.Label style variation msg

values.name: menu
values.comment:
Create a dropdown menu.

This is used with `Input.select`
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Input.Choice option style variation msg) -> Element.Input.Menu option style variation msg

values.name: menuAbove
values.comment: A dropdown menu that goes up! A dropup!
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List.List (Element.Input.Choice option style variation msg) -> Element.Input.Menu option style variation msg

values.name: multiline
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: newPassword
values.comment:
A password input that allows the browser to autofill.

It's `newPassword` instead of just `password` because it gives the browser a hint on what type of password input it is.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: placeholder
values.type: { text : String.String, label : Element.Input.Label style variation msg } -> Element.Input.Label style variation msg

values.name: radio
values.comment:
Input.radio Field
        [ padding 10
        , spacing 20
        ]
        { onChange = ChooseLunch
        , selected = Just model.lunch
        , label = Input.labelAbove (text "Lunch")
        , options = []
        , choices =
            [ Input.styledChoice Burrito <|
                \selected ->
                    Element.row None
                        [ spacing 5 ]
                        [ el None [] <|
                            if selected then
                                text ":D"
                            else
                                text ":("
                        , text "burrito"
                        ]
            , Input.choice Taco (text "Taco!")
            , Input.choice Gyro (text "Gyro")
            ]
        }
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Radio option style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: radioKey
values.comment:
Add a key string to a radio option.

This is used to differentiate between separate radio menus.

It's not needed if the text of the labels are unique.

values.name: radioRow
values.comment: Same as `radio`, but arranges the choices in a row instead of a column
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Radio option style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: search
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: select
values.comment:
This function needs to be paired with either `Input.autocomplete` or `Input.dropMenu`.

    Input.select Field
        [ padding 10
        , spacing 20
        ]
        { label = Input.labelAbove <| text "Lunch"

        -- model.selection is some state(value, a Msg constructor, and the focus) we store in our model.
        -- It can be created using Input.autocomplete or Input.dropMenu
        -- Check out the Form.elm example to see a complete version.
        , with = model.selection
        , max = 5
        , options = []
        , menu =
            Input.menuAbove SubMenu
                []
                [ Input.choice Taco (text "Taco!")
                , Input.choice Gyro (text "Gyro")
                , Input.styledChoice Burrito <|
                    \selected ->
                        Element.row None
                            [ spacing 5 ]
                            [ el None [] <|
                                if selected then
                                    text ":D"
                                else
                                    text ":("
                            , text "burrito"
                            ]
                ]
        }
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Select option style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: selected
values.comment: Get the selected value from an `autocomplete` or a `dropMenu` type that is used for your `Input.select` element.

values.name: styledCheckbox
values.comment:
A checkbox that allows you to style the actual checkbox:

    Input.styledCheckbox Checkbox
        []
        { onChange = Check
        , checked = model.checkbox
        , label = el None [] (text "hello!")
        , options = []
        , icon =
            -- A function which receives a checked bool
            -- and returns the element that represents the checkbox
            \checked ->
                let
                    checkboxStyle =
                        if checked then
                            CheckboxChecked
                        else
                            Checkbox
                in
                el checkboxStyle [] empty
        }
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.StyledCheckbox style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: styledChoice
values.type: value -> (Basics.Bool -> Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Input.Choice value style variation msg

values.name: styledSelectChoice
values.type: value -> (Element.Input.ChoiceState -> Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Input.Choice value style variation msg

values.name: text
values.comment: A plain text input.
values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.type: Element.Input.SelectMsg option -> Element.Input.SelectWith option msg -> Element.Input.SelectWith option msg

values.type: style -> List.List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Input.Text style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

name: Style
comment:
# The Style part of the Style Elements Library!

Here is where you an create your style sheet.

One of the first concepts of `style-elements` is that layout, position, and width/height all live in your view through the `Element` module.

Your style sheet handles everything else!

Check out the other `Style` modules for other properties.

Check out `Basic.elm` in the examples folder to see an example of a full style sheet.


## The Basics

`style-elements` does away with CSS selectors entirely. Every style gets one identifier, which is ultimately rendered as a `class`.

@docs Style, style

Here's a basic example of a style that sets a few colors.

    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Color as Color
    import Color exposing (..)

    type Styles
        = Button

    stylesheet =
        Style.styleSheet
            [ style Button
                [ Color.background blue
                , Color.text white
                ]
            ]
    -- Which can be used in your view as:
    el Button [ ] (text "A button!")

@docs variation

Styles can have variations. Here's what it looks like to have a button style with a variation for `Disabled`

    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Color as Color
    import Color exposing (..)

    type Styles = Button

    -- You need to create a new type to capture variations.
    type Variations
        = Disabled


    stylesheet =
        Style.styleSheet
            [ style Button
                [ Color.background blue
                , Color.text white
                , variation Disabled
                    [ Color.background grey
                    ]
                ]
            ]

    -- which can be rendered in your view as

    el Button [ vary Disabled True ] (text "A Disabled button!")

Before you reach for a variation, consider just creating a subtype. So, something like:

    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Color as Color
    import Color exposing (..)

    type Styles
        = Button ButtonStyles

    type ButtonStyles
        = Active
        | Disabled


    stylesheet =
        Style.stylesheet
            [ style (Button Active)
                [ Color.background blue
                ]
            , style (Button Disabled)
                [ Color.background grey
                ]
            ]

    -- which can be rendered in your view as

    el (Button Active) [] (text "An Active button!")

The main difference between these two is that `variations` can combine with other `variations`, while subtypes are mutually exclusive.


## Properties

@docs Property, prop, opacity, cursor, Font, Color, rgb, rgba


## Transformations

@docs Transform, origin, translate, rotate, rotateAround, scale


## Pseudo Classes

Psuedo classes can be nested.

@docs hover, checked, focus, pseudo


## Render into a Style Sheet

@docs StyleSheet, styleSheet, styleSheetWith, Option, importUrl, importCss

values.comment:
Example:

    style Button
        [ Color.background blue
        , hover
            [ Color.background red
            ]
        ]

values.name: rgb
values.comment: Takes values from 0 to 1 to make a nontransparent color in the rgb space.

values.name: rgba
values.comment: Takes values from 0 to 1 to make a transparent color in the rgb space.

values.name: rotate
values.comment:
Units always rendered as `radians`.

Use `degrees` or `turns` from the standard library if you want to use a different set of units.

values.name: rotateAround
values.comment:
Rotate around a vector.

Angle units always rendered as `radians`.

Use `degrees` or `turns` from the standard library if you want to use a different set of units.
values.type: ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> Basics.Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.type: Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: styleSheetWith

values.name: translate
values.comment: Units are always as pixels
values.type: Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: variation
values.type: variation -> List.List (Style.Property class Basics.Never) -> Style.Property class variation

name: Style.Background

values.name: contain
values.comment: Scale the image proportionally so that it fits entirely in view.

values.name: cover
values.comment: Scale the image proportionally so that it covers the background.

values.name: coverImage
values.comment: A background image that will scale to cover the entire background.

values.name: gradient
values.comment:
Here's an example of creating a background gradient:

    Background.gradient 0 [ step Color.blue, step Color.green]

The first number of the gradient angle given in radians, where 0 is pointing up.
values.type: Basics.Float -> List.List Style.Background.GradientStep -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: height
values.comment: Set only the background image height, the width will be scaled autmatically.

values.name: image
values.comment: A background image that keeps it's natural width and height.

values.name: imageWith
values.type: { src : String.String, position : ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), repeat : Style.Background.Repeat, size : Style.Background.Size } -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: natural
values.comment: Keep the image at it's natural size.

values.name: size
values.comment: Set both the width and height independently. This can potentially skew the image.

values.name: space
values.comment: Leftover space between tiled images will be blank.

values.name: stretch
values.comment: Images will stretch to take up to take up leftover space. Background position will be ignored.

values.name: width
values.comment: Set only the background image width, the height will be scaled autmatically.

name: Style.Border

values.name: none
values.comment: No Borders

values.name: rounded
values.comment: Round all corners.

name: Style.Color
comment:
Set Colors for your style.

Meant to be imported as

    import Style.Color as Color

@docs text, background, border, cursor, decoration, selection, placeholder

values.name: decoration
values.comment: Text decoration color.

values.name: placeholder
values.comment: The color of the input `placeholder` element.

name: Style.Filter
Style.Font

values.name: alignLeft
values.comment: Align the font to the left.

values.name: alignRight
values.comment: Align the font to the right.

values.name: center
values.comment: Align font center.

values.name: letterSpacing
values.comment: In `px`.

values.name: lineHeight
values.comment:
This is the only unitless value in the library that isn't `px`.

Given as a _proportion_ of the `Font.size`.

This means the final lineHeight in px is:

      Font.size * Font.lineHeight == lineHeightInPx

values.name: size
values.comment: Font size as `px`

values.name: wordSpacing
values.comment: In `px`.

name: Style.Scale
comment:
When designing it's nice to use a modular scale to set spacial rythms.

    scaled =
        Scale.modular 16 1.618

A modular scale starts with a number, and multiplies it by a ratio a number of times.

Then, when setting font sizes you can use:

    Font.size (scaled 1) -- results in 16

    Font.size (scaled 2) -- 16 * (1.618 ^ 2) results in 25.8

We can also provide negative numbers to scale below 16px.

@docs modular, roundedModular

values.name: roundedModular
values.comment:
Same a modular but rounds to the nearest integer.

Still returns a Float for compatibility reasons.

name: Style.Shadow
comment:
Shadows

If multiple shadows are set, they will stack.


# Easy Presets

These can be used directly as properties.

    import Color
    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Shadow as Shadow

    style MyStyleWithShadow
        [ Shadow.glow Color.red 5
        ]

@docs simple, deep, glow, innerGlow, textGlow


# Advanced Shadows

You can also have more control over the paraters of the shadow, such as the `Shadow.box` shown below.

    import Color
    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Shadow as Shadow

    style MyStyleWithShadow
        [ Shadow.box
            { offset = ( 0, 0 )
            , size = 5
            , blur = 2
            , color = Color.blue
            }

        ]

@docs box, drop, inset, text

values.name: box
values.type: { offset : ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), size : Basics.Float, blur : Basics.Float, color : Style.Color } -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: deep
values.comment: A nice preset box shadow that's deeper than `simple`.

values.name: drop
values.comment:
A drop shadow will add a shadow to whatever shape you give it.

So, if you apply a drop shadow to an image with an alpha channel, the shadow will appear around the eges.
values.type: { offset : ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), blur : Basics.Float, color : Style.Color } -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: glow
values.comment: A simple glow by specifying the color and size.

values.name: inset
values.type: { offset : ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), size : Basics.Float, blur : Basics.Float, color : Style.Color } -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: simple
values.comment: A nice preset box shadow.

values.name: text
values.type: { offset : ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ), blur : Basics.Float, color : Style.Color } -> Style.Property class variation

name: Style.Sheet
comment:
Combine and mix child stylesheets.

@docs ChildSheet, merge, map, mix

values.name: map
values.type: (class -> parent) -> (variation -> parentVariation) -> List.List (Style.Style class variation) -> Style.Sheet.ChildSheet parent parentVariation

values.name: merge
values.comment: Merge a child stylesheet into a parent.
values.type: Style.Sheet.ChildSheet class variation -> Style.Style class variation

values.name: mix
values.type: List.List (Style.Style class variation) -> Style.Style class variation

aliases.name: Transition
aliases.type: { delay : Style.Transition.Time, duration : Style.Transition.Time, easing : String.String, props : List.List String.String }

values.name: all
values.comment:
Sets transitions on all properties.

It defaults to:

    - 130ms duration
    - "ease" easing.

values.name: performant
values.comment:
This enables transitions on properties that will be GPU accelerated: `transform`, `filter`, and `opacity`.

It defaults to:

    - 130ms duration
    - "ease" easing.

values.name: transitions
values.comment: Create a set of transitions manually.
